Instrument.name: Plasma Wave Receiver for GO
Instrument.description: The Galileo Plasma Wave Receiver, detailed by Gurnett et al. (1992), represents a critical advancement in the investigation of plasma waves and radio emissions in Jupiter's magnetosphere. This study builds on the foundational observations made during the Voyager missions, which identified various complex plasma wave phenomena, including whistler mode emissions, continuum radiation, and electrostatic waves. With the Galileo spacecraft, the first orbiter of Jupiter, the research aims to conduct a comprehensive examination of the Jovian magnetosphere—capturing previously unexplored regions such as the magnetotail, plasma sheet, and Galilean satellites, particularly Io, the primary source of plasma due to its volcanic activity. The instrument is equipped with advanced functionalities, including simultaneous electric and magnetic field measurements and improved frequency/time resolution, enabling both the monitoring of temporal variations and the detection of magnetospheric substorm phenomena. Calibration procedures ensure accurate signal response and noise levels across various frequency channels. Operationally, the PWS employs flexible telemetry modes for low-rate science and wideband waveform data transmission, enhanced following a telecommunications software revamp to mitigate the impact of hardware failures. This extensive capability facilitates detailed analyses of plasma dynamics, contributing to our understanding of magnetospheric processes and their relationship with Io's volcanic activity over extended time scales. The results derived from Galileo’s PWS are poised to provide significant insights into the complex interplay of plasma waves within Jupiter’s magnetosphere.
